author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Kelli Hand, Detroit D.J. and Music Industry Trailblazer, Dies at 56
description: In 2017, the Detroit City Council honored Ms. Hand as the “first lady of Detroit” for her contributions to the techno music scene.
content: Kelli Hand, a longtime disc jockey known as K-Hand who was named the “first lady of Detroit” for her musical accomplishments, was found dead on Aug. 3 at her home in Detroit. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: How a Star Times Reporter Got Paid by Government Agencies He Covered
description: A pair of new books tell how William L. Laurence, a reporter for The New York Times known as ‘Atomic Bill,’ became an apologist for the American military and a serial defier of journalism’s mores.
content: Shortly after the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Maj. Gen. Leslie R. Groves of the U.S. Army, who directed the making of the weapons, told Congress that succumbing to their radiation was “a very pleasant way to die.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Valerie Hopkins
title: Belarus Leader Lashes Out at the West, a Year After Crushing Protests
description: In an eight-hour news conference, President Aleksandr Lukashenko called Britain an “American lapdog” and took credit for averting World War III.
content: MINSK, Belarus — President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the brutal and erratic ruler of Belarus, summoned his acolytes, docile members of the media and a few independent journalists on Monday to present his version of reality: The tens of thousands of Belarusians who rose up in mass protests against his disputed re-election last year were a clueless minority, he said, manipulated by the insidious West seeking to cleave his country from Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Can I Hold Out Hope That My Best Creative Years Are Still to Come?
description: “Let yourself waste time, as if you were young again and too immortal to know any better,” writes our advice columnist.
content: In T’s advice column, Culture Therapist, either Ligaya Mishan or Megan O’Grady solves your problems using art. Have a question? Need some comfort? Email us at advice@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: The Black Reporter Who Exposed a Lie About the Atom Bomb
description: Charles H. Loeb defied the American military’s denials and propaganda to show how deadly radiation from the strike on Hiroshima sickened and killed.
content: “Loeb Reflects On Atomic Bombed Area,” read the headline in The Atlanta Daily World of Oct. 5, 1945, two months after Hiroshima’s ruin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Sharif Hassan and Najim Rahim
title: Fear Sets in as Taliban Seize Former Bastions of Resistance
description: The Taliban’s breakthrough victories across northern Afghanistan have sent despair rippling through the country, as many worry that no corner of the country will be spared.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The families flooded out of northern Afghanistan by the thousands, standing for hours in overcrowded buses and cramming into taxis to escape the Taliban’s swift advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: No Shots, No Service
description: A report from the Bay Area, where a growing number of businesses are requiring that customers show their vaccine cards — or so they say.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The large chalkboard sign in the doorway warned: “Masks and vaccination required!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Mary Inhea Kang
title: The Pandemic Gave New York City ‘Open Streets.’ Will They Survive?
description: 34th Avenue in Queens has become the gold standard for an open street that puts people ahead of cars, but critics say it goes too far.
content: The metal barriers go up every day at 8 a.m. to keep the cars at bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greece works to contain wildfires, as help arrives from other nations.
description: Wildfires were still burning in Turkey and other parts of Europe, where a protracted heat wave has created tinderbox conditions.
content: ATHENS — The effort to stamp out catastrophic wildfires in Greece entered a second week on Monday with foreign countries continuing to send support, and officials began to assess the extent of the damage to thousands of homes and tens of thousands of acres of forest land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Jim Huylebroek
title: On Afghanistan’s Front Line, There Are No Good Choices
description: For the past month, Kandahar, Afghanistan’s second-largest city, has been under siege by Taliban fighters. Families stuck between them and government forces have almost nowhere to go.
content: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — As the first chatter of gunfire began, a police unit tested its heavy machine gun. The gunner pointed the barrel in the vicinity of the Taliban front line and fired in an ear-shattering clap clap clap. Where the bullets landed was anyone’s guess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: 5 takeaways from the major new U.N. climate report.
description: The IPCC concluded that the world cannot avoid some devastating impacts of climate change, but that there is still a narrow window to keep the devastation from getting even worse.
content: On Monday the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a scientific body convened by the United Nations, released a major new report concluding that the world cannot avoid some devastating impacts of climate change, but that there is still a narrow window to keep the devastation from getting even worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A U.S. scientist settled his federal whistle-blowing complaint over Covid treatments.
description: The scientist, Dr. Rick Bright, resigned last year after being demoted by the Trump administration, a step he called retaliation for his warnings about Mr. Trump’s promotion of a drug unproven against Covid-19.
content: Rick Bright, the virologist who claimed the Trump administration retaliated against him last year by ousting him from his job, has settled his whistle-blower complaint against the federal government and will receive back pay and compensation for “emotional stress and reputational damage,” his lawyer said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Covid Vaccines for Kids Can’t Wait
description: The F.D.A. needs to speed up approval of coronavirus jabs for children.
content: A few weeks ago I posted, on Twitter, that I was increasingly furious with the F.D.A. for taking so long to authorize Covid vaccines for children under 12. Then I deleted the tweet, because I know that as desperate as I am to get my kids inoculated, I’m not qualified to make judgments about how the F.D.A. collects safety data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Sergei Kovalev, Longtime Kremlin Adversary, Dies at 91
description: He campaigned for human rights during the Soviet era and continued his activism in the post-Communist years under Boris A. Yeltsin and Vladimir V. Putin.
content: Sergei A. Kovalev, a dogged Kremlin adversary during the Soviet era who went on to campaign against the post-Communist leaders Boris A. Yeltsin and Vladimir V. Putin, died on Monday in Moscow. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Bachelorette’ and Liza Minnelli
description: ABC airs the finale of the “The Bachelorette” Season 17 and PBS brings us to a Liza Minnelli concert.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 9-15. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Get a Covid-19 Vaccine or Face Prison, Judges Order in Probation Cases
description: At least two judges in Ohio have made receiving Covid-19 vaccinations a condition of probation. While judges have leeway in setting such rules, it’s a murky area, experts said.
content: As cases of coronavirus infections rise in Ohio, some judges have attached unusual conditions for those released on probation: Get a Covid-19 vaccine or face being sent to prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: This Is a Terrible Time for Savers
description: In an upside-down world of financial markets, expected returns after inflation are at record lows.
content: If you are saving money for the future, one way or another you had best be prepared to lose some of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats unveil $3.5 trillion budget blueprint, without a measure to raise the debt limit.
description: The policy package could prove to be the most significant change to the nation’s social safety net since Medicare and the Great Society.
content: Democrats formally began their push on Monday for the most significant expansion of the nation’s social safety net since the Great Society of the 1960s, unveiling a budget blueprint that would spend $3.5 trillion on health care, child and elder care, education and climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: After wrangling, the infrastructure bill nears the finish line in the Senate.
description: Senators spent a second weekend in a row wrangling over the details of a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure proposal, putting off a planned summer break. “We’re doing it the old-fashioned way,” Senator Mitt Romney, Republican of Utah, told reporters on Sunday about the many days of debate.
content: Senators spent a second weekend in a row wrangling over the details of a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure proposal, putting off a planned summer break. “We’re doing it the old-fashioned way,” Senator Mitt Romney, Republican of Utah, told reporters on Sunday about the many days of debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Samsung’s de facto leader, imprisoned for bribery, will be paroled.
description: South Korea has been divided over the release of Lee Jae-yong, who has served 60 percent of his two-and-a-half-year prison term.
content: SEOUL — Lee Jae-yong, the de facto leader of the Samsung conglomerate, who was imprisoned for bribery, will be released on parole on Friday, the Ministry of Justice of South Korea said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Frances Robles
title: Biden Ramps Up Pressure on Cuba, Abandoning Obama’s Approach
description: Many Cubans thought the Biden administration would move to normalize relations with Havana. But the president has been tougher than Donald Trump on the island’s government.
content: President Biden’s presidency raised expectations among many Cubans of a return to the Obama days, when the United States sought to bury the last vestige of the Cold War by restoring diplomatic relations with Havana and calling for an end to the embargo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: This Is Rachel Uchitel, Representing Herself
description: For more than a decade, a sweeping nondisclosure agreement with Tiger Woods, brokered by Gloria Allred, has ruled her life. Now she’s ready to rip it up.
content: Rachel Uchitel was sitting at a table in her Upper East Side apartment not long ago, alternately stoic and tearful, surrounded by hundreds of pages of legal documents. For more than a decade these have been familiar company: the wallpaper of a room she can’t seem to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Building to a Vote
description: Senators spent the weekend debating a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure proposal, ultimately clearing the way for a final vote.
content: Senators spent a second weekend in a row wrangling over the details of a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure proposal, putting off a planned summer break. “We’re doing it the old-fashioned way,” Senator Mitt Romney, Republican of Utah, told reporters yesterday about the many days of debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Endless Pleasures of Vegetarian Cooking
description: The world of vegetarian cooking is vast and diverse, and our new newsletter celebrates exactly that.
content: By trade, I’m an omnivore. The only food rule I follow is that I eat everything, because anything can lead to deliciousness. Maybe it’s goat meat on the bone, cooked low and slow and served in a dark pool of its own cooking juices. Maybe it’s a bloomy wheel of cheese made from cashew milk, dense and creamy in the middle. If it’s good, I want it, and then I want seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: When School Nurses Are Not Enough
description: There is no better time than now to bump up the health resources for children in schools, experts say.
content: School children have had an especially challenging time navigating the tedious months of the pandemic, with recent reports showing that students fell four to seven months behind in math and reading compared to previous years, and with the most vulnerable students showing the steepest declines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Top Biden aides are briefed on the mysterious illnesses plaguing U.S. diplomats and spies.
description: President Biden’s top aides were told on Friday that experts studying the mysterious illnesses affecting scores of diplomats, spies and their family members were still struggling to find evidence to back up the leading theory, that microwave attacks are being launched by Russian agents.
content: President Biden’s top aides were told on Friday that experts studying the mysterious illnesses affecting scores of diplomats, spies and their family members were still struggling to find evidence to back up the leading theory, that microwave attacks are being launched by Russian agents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Delta Variant Is Sending More Children to the Hospital. Are They Sicker, Too?
description: It is not yet clear whether the Delta variant causes more severe disease in children, but its high level of infectiousness is causing a surge of pediatric Covid-19 cases.
content: Pilar Villarraga had spent much of the summer counting down the days until her daughter Sophia’s birthday. In early August, Sophia would turn 12 — and become officially eligible for a Covid-19 vaccine. “I didn’t want her to start school without the vaccine,” said Ms. Villarraga, who lives in Doral, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Home for Wondrous Pastries
description: Marvelous by Fred in Midtown is a French pastry shop from Frédéric Vaucamps featuring seven iterations of the merveilleux.
content: The merveilleux, the signature pastry made by Frédéric Vaucamps in Lille, France, has been available in his small shop on Jane Street in the West Village for many years. Now the company, which has 46 shops worldwide, has opened a second New York store, a flagship in Midtown named for the pastry. The feather-light cake and meringue confection, in seven flavors, comes in regular and mini sizes. Brioches, croissants and sandwiches are also sold. The shop, with late 18th-century décor that echoes the post-revolutionary era during which the pastry is said to have been created, includes an enormous crystal chandelier and has seating on two levels indoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Budget Plan, Climate Crisis, Military Vaccines: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Comic Book Writers and Artists Follow Other Creators to Substack
description: A group of creators will publish new comic book stories, essays and how-to guides on the platform as a way to connect directly with fans.
content: In recent years, dozens of top journalists, historians and essayists have tried their luck as solo practitioners on Substack, the digital newsletter platform that has built an audience of more than 500,000 subscribers since it started in 2017. Now, a number of comic book creators have decided to do the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Getting Old Is a Crisis More and More Americans Can’t Afford
description: The looming financial crisis for seniors.
content: Growing old is an increasingly expensive privilege often requiring supports and services that, whether provided at home or in a facility, can overwhelm all but the wealthiest seniors. With Americans living longer and aging baby boomers flooding the system, the financial strain is becoming unsustainable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Keep It Casual in Earth Tones
description: A new line of table linens from a Los Angeles company adds breezy elegance to summer meals.
content: Checked tablecloths and napkins are common in your neighborhood bistro, red sauce joint or summer picnic basket. But at Morrow Soft Goods, a Los Angeles company owned by Michelle Toney and Stephanie Cleary, the gingham for its line of 100 percent linen table wares is subtler than the typical red, in tones like honey and cream. Until now, the company has specialized in linen bedding. The new kitchen and dining collection features napkins and place mats ($55 to $70 for four), tablecloths ($119 to $125), and aprons ($50 to $55) in checks, and in earthy solids like sage, terra cotta and apricot, colors that will easily take you into fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Add Green to Your Salt Lineup
description: A lower-sodium salt substitute from the Baja Peninsula of Mexico is made with salicornia, a halophyte.
content: Your salt wardrobe may already include black and pink. But what about green? A new naturally green salt substitute produced from salicornia, a halophyte, has hit the market. Decades ago, José Ramón Noriega planted salicornia on salt-affected farmland in northern Baja California, Mexico. Now his sons, Paul, Erick and Irving Noriega, and another partner, Chris Lin, are cultivating the crop organically, dehydrating and pulverizing it to make a salty powder they call Green Salt. It’s salty enough to use in place of table salt, though it’s substantially lower in sodium. It adds a nice touch of vegetal flavor when dusted atop a deviled egg, baked potato or sautéed fish. That flavor disappears in cake batter or pasta sauce. While Green Salt is more costly than regular kosher or sea salt, it’s comparable in price to many boutique salts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Executive Assistant Who Accused Cuomo of Groping Says It Was ‘Not Normal’
description: Brittany Commisso, who filed a criminal complaint against Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, spoke publicly for the first time about her allegations.
content: Brittany Commisso, the executive assistant who accused Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of groping her in the Executive Mansion and filed a criminal complaint against him, forcefully rebutted the governor’s claims that she initiated or welcomed physical contact between them, in an interview that aired on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Elizabeth Warren will propose a minimum tax on the nation’s richest companies.
description: Ms. Warren’s proposal would be a part of the $3.5 trillion economic and social-policy package.
content: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and her allies will propose a minimum tax on the profits of the nation’s richest companies, regardless of what they say they owe the government, as part of Democrats’ $3.5 trillion economic and social-policy package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Dallas school district defies governor’s ban and announces a mask mandate.
description: The temporary rule contradicted an executive order by Gov. Greg Abbott that prohibits school districts from requiring masks.
content: The Dallas Independent School District said on Monday that everyone — students, employees and visitors — must wear a mask while on school property, starting Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: ‘The Standard American Diet Kills Us Slowly in Normal Times and Quickly in Covid Times’
description: Michael Pollan discusses his psychedelic journey and what highly processed foods are doing to our bodies.
content: Michael Pollan has brewed tea from opium poppies, quit caffeine cold turkey and tried mescaline, a psychedelic found in some kinds of cactus. While the author’s past works have taken on the Western diet and the cultural attitude toward psychedelics, in “This Is Your Mind on Plants” Pollan wages a war against — well, the government’s war on drugs. He argues that the approach to regulation has been selective and self-serving, making him “question whether the real rationale of the drug war was ever public health.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Can Fruits and Vegetables Boost Brain Health?
description: Flavonoids, the chemicals that give plant foods their bright colors, may help curb the frustrating forgetfulness and mild confusion of advancing age.
content: Eating colorful fruits and vegetables may be good for your brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ed Shanahan
title: Virginia Giuffre Files Lawsuit Accusing Prince Andrew of Rape
description: Ms. Giuffre, one of the most outspoken of Jeffrey Epstein’s accusers, said in a lawsuit that Andrew, the Duke of York, had sexually abused her when she was 17.
content: Virginia Giuffre, one of Jeffrey Epstein’s most prominent accusers, sued Prince Andrew in New York on Monday, saying that the scion of Britain’s royal family had raped and sexually abused her when she was 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Playlist for the Apocalypse,’ the Weight of American History and of Mortality
description: Rita Dove’s latest collection of poems is about this “shining, blistered republic” and her own health troubles.
content: It’s incumbent on the author of a good book to provide an apt title. Would we feel the same way about Faulkner’s “Intruder in the Dust” if it were called, as he once considered, “Malpractice in the Dust”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: This Flower Hides a Secret: It’s Actually a Carnivore
description: That this perennial wildflower digests trapped insects suggests that other plants’ appetites for animals may be overlooked.
content: This wildflower looks innocent. Found in wetlands not far from major cities in the Pacific Northwest, it lures in pollinators with white blossoms atop a long, sticky stem. You can even buy seeds of the Western false asphodel in garden stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Mystery Attacks on Diplomats Leave Scores of Victims but Still Little Evidence
description: While the leading theory in the “Havana syndrome” cases is directed microwave attacks, a classified session for senior government officials said months of investigation were inconclusive.
content: President Biden’s top aides were told on Friday that experts studying the mysterious illnesses affecting scores of diplomats, spies and their family members were still struggling to find evidence to back up the leading theory, that microwave attacks are being launched by Russian agents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, J. David Goodman and Jeffery C. Mays
title: A Defiant Cuomo Seeks to Buy Time as Lawmakers Prepare for Impeachment
description: Legislators could decide by early next month to try to force the governor from office over allegations that he sexually harassed 11 women.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Defiant yet increasingly alone, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo determined in recent days that his best chance at political survival is to drag out the process of his possible impeachment over allegations that he sexually harassed nearly a dozen women, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Deadly Clashes Threaten South Sudan’s Shaky Peace Deal
description: Infighting within the vice president’s party is undermining an already unstable ruling alliance that was formed after a five-year civil war killed 400,000 people.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — A decade after South Sudan gained independence amid much hope and fanfare, the country’s path to lasting stability remains fragile as infighting tears at the shaky coalition governing the world’s youngest nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Hiroko Tabuchi and Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: Climate Change Is a ‘Hammer Hitting Us on the Head,’ Developing Nations Say
description: Leaders of vulnerable countries, as well as activists, said Monday’s blistering United Nations report must galvanize global action. But major emitters are dragging their heels.
content: When some 200 scientists convened by the United Nations all but demanded on Monday that the nations immediately band together to cut emissions, they portrayed it as a brief window to avert the most catastrophic impacts of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: The Stigma of a Scarlet E
description: Eviction cases — called Scarlet E’s — are a stubborn blot on a renter’s history. Piecemeal privacy legislation in some states may not be enough to protect millions of struggling tenants.
content: The apartment was just what Chanque Jones needed: four bedrooms, and $500 cheaper than the run-down house she had been renting back in Chicago. It was a fresh start for her three sons, as well as for her mobile manicure business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Britney Spears Judge Denies Motion to Expedite Hearing About Her Father
description: A judge overseeing the singer’s case ruled that a court date to address removing or suspending James P. Spears as conservator would remain scheduled for September.
content: A judge overseeing the conservatorship of Britney Spears has denied a request to expedite a forthcoming hearing that will focus on whether to remove or suspend the singer’s father from a role in directing the legal arrangement, as a new lawyer for Ms. Spears recently petitioned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: The Biden administration imposes another round of sanctions on Belarus.
description: The move marked the anniversary of an election that the country’s president claimed he won with 80 percent of the vote.
content: President Biden imposed a new round of economic sanctions on Belarus on Monday, marking the anniversary of an election that many Western governments view as fraudulent and that spurred mass protests in the former Soviet Union country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Henry Fountain
title: A major new report finds some of the devastating impacts of global warming are now unavoidable.
description: Nations have delayed curbing their fossil-fuel emissions for so long that they can no longer stop global warming from intensifying over the next 30 years, though there is still a short window to prevent the most harrowing future, a major new United Nations scientific report has concluded.
content: Nations have delayed curbing their fossil-fuel emissions for so long that they can no longer stop global warming from intensifying over the next 30 years, though there is still a short window to prevent the most harrowing future, a major new United Nations scientific report has concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: ‘There Is a Right and Wrong Way to Tickle a Rat’
description: Researchers in Australia tickled the rodents every day for a month to see if it would improve their emotional well-being.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — It’s generally not a good time to be a rodent in Australia. On farms across the country, mice are being poisoned and chased out of fields by desperate farmers as the country suffers one of the worst mouse plagues in living memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Judge allows cruise line to temporarily require proof of vaccination in Florida.
description: The order lets Norwegian Cruise Line demand proof of vaccination from passengers, despite a state law that prohibits such requirements.
content: A federal judge on Sunday granted Norwegian Cruise Line’s request for a preliminary injunction, temporarily allowing the company to require proof of vaccination from passengers despite a Florida law that bans businesses from doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathy Castor
title: To Address the Climate Crisis, Focus on More Than Carbon Dioxide
description: Methane is yet another obstacle in the path to combatting climate change.
content: In conversations around the climate crisis, there’s often a focus on carbon dioxide. It is trapping heat and warming our atmosphere, fueling deadlier climate disasters than normal and costing billions year after year. We are right to focus on carbon dioxide. In 2019, it made up about 80 percent of human-caused, heat-trapping pollution in the United States. Reducing it remains the key to achieving as soon as possible a net-zero economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A major climate report presents bleak findings.
content: Nations have delayed curbing fossil fuels for so long that they can no longer stop global warming from intensifying over the next 30 years, though there is still a short window to prevent the most harrowing future, a major new U.N. report has concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Kai Chen
title: Settling Scores at a Fist-Fighting Festival in the Peruvian Andes
description: Each year on Dec. 25, thousands of locals gather in the town of Santo Tomás — dressed in elaborate costumes — to dance, drink and duke it out.
content: A light rain fell as I fought through a sea of masked fighters for a glimpse into the center ring. From a few feet away, I watched as two local fighters struck at each other with their bare fists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Troy Closson
title: After Key Evidence Was Withheld, 2 Men Spent 3 Decades in Prison
description: Carlton Roman and Christopher Ellis were freed after judges in separate cases found that they had been unjustly convicted.
content: At the time of one murder, in 1989 in Queens, Carlton Roman was running errands with his fiancée and infant daughter. When an unrelated killing occurred on Long Island in 1990, Christopher Ellis was DJing his brother’s birthday party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck
title: Turning on Cuomo, Democrats Begin to Consider the 2022 Field
description: Potential successors are in the wings. But the longer it takes for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s fate to be resolved, the greater the headache for Democrats.
content: When an independent report declared last week that one of the nation’s most prominent Democratic leaders had sexually harassed 11 women, even some of his closest friends and oldest allies had finally run out of patience with Andrew M. Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A surge among children
content: Coronavirus cases among children are surging across the U.S., with some doctors seeing more critically ill pediatric patients than at any other point during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Taliban take three more cities.
content: The Taliban seized three Afghan cities yesterday — the commercial hub of Kunduz, Sar-i-Pul and Taliqan, all in the north — in a staggering advance, as government forces struggled to hold the line. Even more populous cities are under siege, a devastating setback for the Afghan government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Billie Eilish, 21st-Century Pop Paragon, Hits No. 1 With Big Vinyl Sales
description: “Happier Than Ever” debuted at the top of the Billboard 200 with 54 percent of its total from physical formats.
content: Billie Eilish emerged a few years ago as the embodiment of the new-model pop star — flooding the internet with content, designing merch items herself and accumulating boatloads of fans through social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Champagne Wishes and Climate Change Dreams
description: A new documentary on Champagne explores its roots in France, but also how sparkling wines have flourished across the English Channel thanks to global warming.
content: A new documentary, “Sparkling: The Story of Champagne,” is a lush valentine to the French bubbly, with history, profiles of many of the producers, pithy quotes about the wine, its celebrity connections (notably Winston Churchill) and tidbits about Champagne in the United States. But perhaps more compelling is its coverage of English sparkling wines, a less well-known topic. Climate change has turned the south of England into sparkling wine country, something the French acknowledge onscreen, with admiration; some French producers now own vineyards in England. But whether France is ready to credit England with having discovered champagne before Dom Pérignon’s 17th-century epiphany, a controversy the film examines, or whether James Bond will forgo his Bollinger for Hush Heath Estate, one of the English houses in the film, remains to be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘The Tempest’ Starkly Amplifies Prospero’s Evolution
description: A strong ensemble, music and movement round out the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival’s last production in its longtime home at Boscobel House and Gardens.
content: GARRISON, N.Y. — Prospero’s grievance has been gnawing at him a dozen years when at last he speaks of it to his teenage daughter, Miranda, explaining how they were forced from their noble life in Milan into island exile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: Business Travel Resumes, Hesitantly
description: Convention centers are reopening. Hotels and airlines report an uptick in bookings. But the rise in virus cases has tempered forecasts for a major recovery.
content: Business travel has started again, but in fits and starts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Arrogance of Power Has Limits. Just Ask Cuomo.
description: He’s finding out the hard way.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, we’ve been agreeing about a heck of a lot this summer. You like the Olympics and Biden’s infrastructure bill. Let me guess that we’re also on the same page when it comes to Andrew Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Reopens to Vaccinated Americans but Few Rush to the Border
description: Carrying watercraft, bikes and hopes for a salvaged summer, some American travelers ventured north on the first day of the border reopening.
content: LANSDOWNE, Ontario — When Heidi Linckh peered down at the border between Canada and the United States from the 400-foot-high sightseeing lookout she owns with her husband on Monday, she saw something that had been long been missing from the view: a string of passenger cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Chicago Improv Was Dead. Can New Leaders Revive It?
description: The past year left the city’s two most prominent institutions reeling. Now, outsiders are helping to guide the re-emergence of these celebrated comedy centers.
content: CHICAGO — Fourteen months after iO Theater closed its doors because of the pandemic, a move that seemed temporary at the time, the storied improv center looked as though it had been frozen in time, the calendar stuck on March 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Tariq Panja
title: Tokyo’s Olympic Bubble? Wait Till You See Beijing’s.
description: For the Winter Games, just six months away, China plans far more elaborate Covid-19 precautions than were taken at the Summer Olympics.
content: BEIJING — Guards in biohazard suits, ready to stop anyone from leaving. Athletes giving interviews from behind plastic walls, speaking through microphones. All-day armpit thermometers, with tiny transmitters to sound the alarm should someone develop a fever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Even Your Allergist Is Now Investing in Start-Ups
description: The once-clubby world of start-up deal making known as “angel investing” has had an influx of new participants. It’s part of a wider boom in ever-riskier investments.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — On a recent Wednesday evening, 60 people gathered in a virtual conference room to discuss start-up investments. Among them were a professional poker player from Arizona, an allergist in California and a kombucha maker from Tennessee. All were members of Angel Squad, a six-month $2,500 program that aims to help people break into the clubby world of venture capital as individual investors, known as “angels.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor and Michael Gold
title: Roberta Kaplan, Who Aided Cuomo, Resigns from Time’s Up
description: Ms. Kaplan, a prominent progressive lawyer, was involved in an effort to discredit a woman who had accused Gov. Andrew Cuomo of sexual harassment, a report said.
content: The fallout from a damaging report that found Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo sexually harassed 11 women widened on Monday when Roberta A. Kaplan, a nationally prominent lawyer with ties to the governor, resigned from Time’s Up, the organization founded by Hollywood women to fight sexual abuse and promote gender equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Rockies Now Say Fan Was Calling to Mascot, Not Shouting a Slur
description: What seemed to be a case of overt racism was actually a misunderstanding, the team said.
content: After investigating reports that a fan had yelled a racial slur during a game at Coors Field in Denver on Sunday, the Colorado Rockies determined the fan was actually yelling for the team mascot, Dinger, the team said in a statement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Gold Medals in Style From the 2020 Tokyo Olympics
description: Athletes, performers and commentators offered up winning looks while competing at the highest level.
content: The 2020 Olympics in Tokyo have been among the strangest in memory. Delayed by a year, and unloved and underway in a host city that didn’t want them, the Games have still provided a bevy of brilliant sporting stories, including bold debuts and smashed records, underdog triumphs and superstar broken hearts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Senate Democrats Begin $3.5 Trillion Push for ‘Big, Bold’ Social Change
description: A Senate budget blueprint, which Democrats hope to pass this week, would ease passage of legislation that would mark the biggest expansion of the social safety net in nearly 60 years.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats formally began their push on Monday for the most significant expansion of the nation’s social safety net since the Great Society of the 1960s, unveiling a budget blueprint that would spend $3.5 trillion on health care, child and elder care, education and climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A Queens Avenue Shows How City Streets Can be Reimagined
description: Some praise the greater space for outdoor activities, while critics point to disruptions to traffic and parking.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After 7th Straight Gold, U.S. Looks to a New Era
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 9, 2021
content: “At the opening ceremony, I was like: ‘Five times? My feet hurt!’ But it’s real. It makes you want to come back and continue to give and to build for the next generation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: ‘West Side Story’ Will Not Return to Broadway
description: The reimagined revival was closed by the pandemic, and then its lead producer, Scott Rudin, said he would step back from active participation in his shows after being accused of bullying.
content: “West Side Story,” an ambitious, reimagined revival of the classic musical, will not reopen when Broadway returns this fall, the show announced Monday, making it one of the biggest productions yet to become a casualty of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: When Sickness Eclipses Health, How Does a Marriage Survive?
description: Eleanor Henderson chronicles her family’s herculean struggle with illness in her memoir, “Everything I Have Is Yours.”
content: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: How to Make a Neighborhood Farm for an Entire Metropolis
description: A program being started in Atlanta helps midsize farmers buy their own land while providing much-needed fresh food to urban consumers.
content: ATLANTA — Joe Reynolds and Judith Winfrey, the married couple who started Love Is Love Farm 13 years ago not far from downtown Atlanta, are part of a generation of landless America farmers who grow food in rented fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: At Least One Thing Good Came Out of 2020
description: Some of the herbaceous extra-virgin olive oils made in Tuscany are among the best the founder of the Rare Wine Company has tasted.
content: Olive oil is made all over Italy, but no region produces oils as singular as those from Tuscany. Mannie Berk, the president of the Rare Wine Company in Brisbane, Calif., is a connoisseur who has had Tuscan extra-virgin olive oils bottled for his company since 1995. Lately, he has found them lacking their customary verve and intensity, a shortcoming he attributes to global warming. But not those made in 2020. He raves about the vintage. Though his company imports 22 different oils, some are worth knowing, like leccino oils by Pruneti, a classic; and Sàgona, more forceful, $59.99 for both. A new oil for his company is the herbaceous Fonte di Foiano 1979 from the Bolgheri region, sold as part of a set of six from areas in and around Chianti for $157.50. Also in that set is the Volpaia from the Classico district, a blend of several olives that’s deep green, minty and viscous with bracing bitterness. The oils, all sold in half-liter bottles, are to use for finishing, not sautéing, to elevate a bowl of pappa al pomodoro or grilled fennel, or to trace over slices of rosemary-scented pork roast.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Billie Eilish’s New Pop Perspective
description: How has the teenage phenomenon’s songwriting, and her relationship to the larger music machine, evolved between albums?
content: When Billie Eilish swept the biggest Grammy categories in early 2020, she was a phenomenon, yet somehow not quite a pop star. Her music tended toward the gloomy and insular, and her ravenous fan base was built online among young people, not on the radio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.3 Million Homes in California
description: A 1938 chalet-style house in Orinda, an 1885 Victorian in St. Helena and a hotel-inspired contemporary home in Cardiff-by-the-Sea.
content: Much of Orinda, a small city about 15 minutes from Oakland, was developed in the 1920s by Edward Ignacio de Laveaga, whose family hired Italian craftsmen to build this house in the late 1930s. The home was remodeled by the current owner, who worked with preservation and materials experts to maintain its historic character.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Bolsonaro May Not Actually Succeed in Destroying Us All
description: He tried. But he couldn’t crack Brazilians’ unbreakable love of vaccines.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — I don’t know if it’s because I finally got my first Covid shot — maybe hope is a side effect of the AstraZeneca vaccine — but for the first time in this long pandemic, I feel that President Jair Bolsonaro may not succeed in destroying us all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Najim Rahim and Sharif Hassan
title: The Taliban take a sixth provincial capital as government forces reel.
description: Reeling on the battlefield, Afghan government officials face the difficult question of whether to let captured cities go in order to hold what they still have.
content: The Taliban seized near total control over another provincial capital in northern Afghanistan on Monday, local and security officials said, a day after the insurgent group took three others, including the strategic and economically important city of Kunduz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Climate Denial, Covid Denial and the Right’s Descent
description: It’s not as bad as you thought. It’s worse.
content: Before the right embraced Covid denial, there was climate denial. Many of the attitudes that have characterized the right-wing response to the coronavirus pandemic — refusal to acknowledge facts, accusations that scientists are part of a vast liberal conspiracy, refusal to address the crisis — were foreshadowed in the climate debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers, Heather Murphy and Charlie Savage
title: U.S. Signals It Will Release Some Still-Secret Files on Saudi Arabia and 9/11
description: The F.B.I. said it would review some long-classified documents for possible disclosure, a decision that followed a push by families of the attacks’ victims.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration, under pressure from families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, said on Monday that it intended to disclose some long-classified documents that the families think could detail connections between the government of Saudi Arabia and the hijackers who carried out the attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Don’t Want to Spend the Rest of My Days Grieving
description: I remind myself to attend to what is not dying, to focus as much on the exquisite beauties of this earth as on its staggering losses.
content: NASHVILLE — Sometimes I remember how I tried to comfort my children when they encountered a setback or were disappointed that a dream they were nurturing had not yet come true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Consumers are on the lookout for higher prices, a Federal Reserve survey shows.
description: The rise in the longer-term price gauge was small, but Fed officials are closely watching such metrics.
content: Expectations for long-term inflation rose slightly in July, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said on Monday, and consumers continued to foresee rapid price gains in the near term as the economy reopens from pandemic-related lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharif Hassan
title: The insurgents’ success in northern Afghanistan is an ill omen for Kabul.
description: In 1996, the Taliban captured Kabul before turning to the north. This time, they have already swept across a region that once defied them.
content: Since the Taliban emerged in the 1990s, Afghanistan’s north has been the heart of resistance to the insurgents — predominantly ethnic Pashtun and from the south — and a bulwark against a complete takeover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo’s Top Aide, Melissa DeRosa, Resigns as He Fights to Survive
description: The governor’s strategist helped lead efforts to retaliate against one of the women who accused him of sexual harassment, the attorney general’s report found.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s top aide, Melissa DeRosa, said late Sunday that she had resigned, a move that came as the governor fought for political survival after a report from the New York State attorney general concluded he had sexually harassed nearly a dozen women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Henry Fountain
title: A Hotter Future Is Certain, Climate Panel Warns. But How Hot Is Up to Us.
description: Some devastating impacts of global warming are now unavoidable, a major new scientific report finds. But there is still a short window to stop things from getting even worse.
content: Nations have delayed curbing their fossil-fuel emissions for so long that they can no longer stop global warming from intensifying over the next 30 years, though there is still a short window to prevent the most harrowing future, a major new United Nations scientific report has concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery, Giulia Heyward and Edgar Sandoval
title: Abbott Criticized for Ban on Covid Mandates as Cases Soar in Texas
description: Gov. Greg Abbott joins other Republican leaders standing by their orders against mandates for masks and vaccines.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — The dilemma sounded familiar. A prominent, ambitious red-state governor, who had staked out a firm position opposed to mask mandates and other aggressive measures to combat the spread of Covid-19, suddenly found himself on the defensive as cases and hospitalizations soared in his state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn, Niraj Chokshi and Roger Kisby
title: Electric Cars for Everyone? Not Unless They Get Cheaper.
description: President Biden has made conversion to E.V.s a pillar of climate policy. But government incentives mostly help affluent buyers, not average families.
content: SAN DIEGO — Robert Teglia bought a Tesla Model 3 sedan even though he knew it cost more than many luxury cars. He didn’t particularly care that it might be better than the others for the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Robert Carsen Is Opera’s Most Reliably Excellent Director
description: If you’re an opera fan, chances are you’ve seen one of his productions. The latest, a Handel oratorio, is running at the Salzburg Festival.
content: SALZBURG, Austria — “I personally don’t like the word ‘reliable,’” Robert Carsen said in an interview here recently. “It sounds so boring.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Céline Gounder, John P. Moore and Carlos del Rio
title: Do You Need Another Covid Shot?
description: Are multiple doses better than one?
content: The spread of Delta and rising reports of breakthrough infections raise questions about whether the vaccinated might need a “booster” dose. For Americans who received the Pfizer or Moderna mRNA vaccines, that may mean a third shot. For people who got the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, that could mean a second dose of the same vaccine or even an mRNA shot instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lorella Praeli and Hina Naveed
title: This Can Be the Year We Fulfill Our Promise to Dreamers
description: Young undocumented immigrants have waited long enough to plan their lives.
content: We were each 10 when our families — Lorella’s from Peru, Hina’s from Pakistan — moved with us to the United States. Our parents arrived here determined to find the best medical care. For Hina’s sister Aleeza, America meant treatment for a life-threatening brain condition that doctors in Dubai and India warned was available nowhere else. For Lorella, whose right leg was amputated after a car accident in Peru, the United States held the promise of advanced prosthetics and a country where she could thrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A Hotter Future
description: Human activity has significantly heated the Earth already. But several climate futures are still possible.
content: It’s too late to reverse the damage done to the Earth’s climate. It’s not too late to change course right away to prevent things from getting far worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery, Giulia Heyward and Edgar Sandoval
title: Abbott is criticized for his ban on mask mandates as cases soar in Texas.
description: The dilemma sounded familiar. A prominent, ambitious red-state governor, who had staked out a firm position opposed to mask mandates and other aggressive measures to combat the spread of the virus, suddenly found himself on the defensive as cases and hospitalizations soared in his state.
content: The dilemma sounded familiar. A prominent, ambitious red-state governor, who had staked out a firm position opposed to mask mandates and other aggressive measures to combat the spread of the virus, suddenly found himself on the defensive as cases and hospitalizations soared in his state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Jay-Z’s ‘Black Album’ Helped Me Beat the Odds. Will We Finally Even Them?
description: In 2003, our writer absorbed the rapper’s message of individual triumph. But in a new moment of collective action, it’s time to write new rules.
content: In my senior year of high school, I joined the student council. I knew that it might look fishy — adding on another extracurricular so late in the game — but I figured making the effort could also work in my favor. I imagined eagle-eyed college admissions officers poring over my file, spotting any latent passions discovered in the heat of application season. Half amused, they would scribble their verdict in the margins: “Shameless but hungry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Rockies Investigating Whether Fan Shouted Racial Slur at a Marlins Player
description: The incident happened during the ninth inning on Sunday while Lewis Brinson, who is Black, was hitting.
content: The Colorado Rockies are investigating whether a man in the stands at Coors Field in Denver on Sunday repeatedly and loudly yelled a racial slur at Miami Marlins outfielder Lewis Brinson, who is Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A Lifeline to Let College Teams Play On
description: The University of Alaska Anchorage set specific goals for targeted teams to survive. Millions of dollars poured in, suggesting a template for schools hoping to keep programs afloat.
content: ANCHORAGE — The gymnastics coach at the University of Alaska Anchorage called last August, just as Brooklyn Kopsack checked into her freshman dorm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Washington State sets vaccine mandate for government and health care workers.
description: Employees who refuse to get vaccinated would face losing their jobs, Gov. Jay Inslee said.
content: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington announced Monday that most state employees and all health care workers must be fully vaccinated against the coronavirus by Oct. 18, or risk losing their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Despite the Dixie Fire’s destruction, some residents aren’t evacuating.
description: Temperatures across Northern California will trend warmer on Monday and Tuesday as an excessive heat watch settles in for the remainder of the week.
content: As the Dixie Fire ravaging Northern California became the state’s second largest on record over the weekend, efforts to save tinder dry land, towns and homes from being destroyed have been complicated by residents who aren’t heeding one order: evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The U.S. military will mandate Covid-19 vaccines for troops.
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said he will issue the order once the F.D.A. has fully approved the vaccine. If that hasn’t occurred by mid-September, he may seek to do it anyway.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon will seek to make coronavirus vaccinations mandatory for the country’s 1.3 million active-duty troops “no later” than the middle of next month, the Biden administration announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Book to Inspire in the Kitchen
description: For her new book, “Why We Cook,” the illustrator Lindsay Gardner spoke to more than 100 women about the allure of food.
content: Through a series of profiles, reminiscences, essays, interviews and recipes, “Why We Cook” explores many facets of women in the world of food. More than 100 chefs, writers, entrepreneurs, farmers, wine experts and educators contributed to this lively book. The bright illustrations are by the author, Lindsay Gardner, who seeks to understand exactly why she turned to the kitchen; she thought others could address that question, too. Reem Assil, Amanda Cohen, Joyce Goldstein, Christine Ha, Deborah Madison, Jen Pelka, Ruth Reichl, Jordan Salcito and Bonnie Tsui are among the women whose opinions appear. It’s a book to browse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Weiner
title: This Is No Way to Rule a Country
description: Why are members of Congress and the president eager to endorse each other's authority without exercising their own?
content: A curious constitutional drama unfolded in the nation’s capital last week. Having failed to pass a moratorium on evictions, members of Congress took to the steps of the U.S. Capitol to demand that President Biden impose one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: The Education Department ends its effort to stop states from suing federal student loan servicers.
description: The move reverses a Trump administration policy aimed at sheltering the department’s contractors from state oversight.
content: In its latest move to undo Trump-era policies, the Education Department said on Monday that states are free to police federal student loan servicers that run afoul of local consumer protection laws, reversing its previous legal stance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Covering a Weird Olympics
description: A diver’s heartbreaking scratch. A medalist lifting up a teammate. Cherished glimpses of Japanese culture — our journalists saw a lot viewers may not have.
content: Members of The New York Times staff at the Tokyo Olympics reflected on moments that will stay with them from a Games undercut by the pandemic but filled with emotional twists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Fund for Jeffrey Epstein’s Victims Has Paid Out More Than $121 Million
description: The administrator of the fund said she wanted to approve the final awards before Tuesday — the second anniversary of Mr. Epstein’s death.
content: The fund created by the estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein to compensate victims of sexual assault by the financier has wrapped up its work by paying out just over $121 million to more than 135 people — far more than expected, according to the fund’s administrator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka, Thomas Fuller and Jack Healy
title: The Ashes of the Dixie Fire Cast a Pall 1,000 Miles From Its Flames
description: The megafires of the West are sending out giant clouds of smoke and leaving a footprint much larger than the evergreen forests they level and the towns they decimate.
content: TAYLORSVILLE, Calif. — Captured by an astronaut’s camera, the Dixie Fire appears as a thick and sickening miasma pouring from the earth’s surface. At its center in the eastern mountains of California, the fire is devouring acre after acre of rugged wildland to become the second largest blaze in the state’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Lara Jakes
title: The Senate moves toward final passage of the $1 trillion infrastructure deal.
description: Absent unanimous agreement to expedite the process, the bill may not pass until Tuesday morning because Senate rules require 30 hours of debate.
content: The Senate trudged on Monday toward final passage of a bipartisan $1 trillion infrastructure package, after clearing the last significant procedural hurdles for the legislation over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Text Memes Are Taking Over Instagram
description: Fueled by Gen Z, text-heavy meme posts, often paired with nonsensically unrelated pictures, are turning the photo and video app into a destination for written expression.
content: LOS ANGELES — Last month, the singer Courtney Love, who is a keen observer of social media trends, posted a cryptic message on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gao
title: ‘Fantasy Island’ Returns, Now With a Ms. Roarke
description: Roselyn Sánchez leads this Fox reboot of the beloved ABC series, playing a grandniece of Ricardo Montalbán’s white-suited steward of a mystical isle.
content: More than 37 years after Ricardo Montalbán finished his run as Mr. Roarke, the debonair concierge of an enigmatic, wish-fulfilling beach resort in the Pacific Ocean, “Fantasy Island” is returning once more to network television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: Families of High-Risk Children Despair Over Covid Resurgence
description: When a 7-year-old in Utah tested positive for the coronavirus, his mother vented her frustration on social media. Low vaccination rates in her state are to blame, she says.
content: On the July evening that he was diagnosed with Covid-19, 7-year-old Ethan Chandra lay in bed with a high fever next to his mother, holding her hand and whispering, “I’m scared I’m going to die.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Suspect in Fire at French Cathedral Is Arrested in Killing of a Priest
description: The arrest of the suspect, a Rwandan asylum-seeker facing deportation, fueled criticism of the government’s immigration laws by right-wing politicians.
content: PARIS — A church volunteer awaiting trial in an arson incident last summer at a 15th-century cathedral was arrested on Monday after confessing to killing a Roman Catholic priest in the Vendée region in western France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canadian wildfires could intensify from a looming heat wave.
description: Wildfires are burning from Ontario to hard-hit British Columbia, where more than 1.5 million acres have been scorched since April.
content: As Canada battled wildfires from its west coast to the prairies, another blistering heat wave threatened to descend this week on British Columbia, where more than a million acres have burned since April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Shower Curtains
description: You don’t have to spend a lot of money to make your bathroom look better. Try a new shower curtain for a quick, affordable fix.
content: If renovating your bathroom isn’t in the budget this year, don’t despair. Try changing your shower curtain instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Boutsalis
title: ‘This Is What We Should Have Had All Along’
description: In a group interview, Native American TV creators and performers discuss the significance of “Reservation Dogs” and “Rutherford Falls,” and why this is only the beginning.
content: “What we’ve been doing this last year is way bigger than I had in my dreams,” the Ponca and Ojibwe writer and producer Migizi Pensoneau said recently. “You think it’s going to be this incremental thing and then suddenly there are these two massive TV shows, and the aftershocks are going to be massive, too.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Unsettling heat will scorch much of the U.S. again this week.
description: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world. Follow here for news on heat waves, wildfires, floods and more.
content: Seattle’s second-longest dry streak on record ended late last week when light rain fell for the first time in 51 days. But the region is expected to once again bake under an intense heat wave this week, meteorologists said, with triple-digit temperatures amid the already dry conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Trevor Moore, Co-Founder of ‘Whitest Kids U’Know’ Comedy Show, Dies at 41
description: The comedian, who released a solo album called “Drunk Texts to Myself” and whose films included “The Civil War on Drugs,” was killed in an unexplained accident.
content: Trevor Moore, a comedian and co-founder of the popular sketch comedy show “The Whitest Kids U’Know,” which appeared on the Independent Film Channel, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Eric Krupke, Annie Brown, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Back to School Amid the Delta Variant
description: As students prepare for a return to in-person learning, conflicts have arisen in several U.S. states over mask mandates in schools.
content: The Delta variant of the coronavirus is looming large over this year’s back-to-school preparations in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside a Louisiana Hospital Battling the Delta Variant
description: Like many hospitals in Louisiana, North Oaks Medical Center has been tested by a fourth wave of coronavirus cases.
content: Like many hospitals in Louisiana, North Oaks Medical Center has been tested by a fourth wave of coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Letter
description: Roberta Kaplan resigned as chairwoman of Time’s Up after a report revealed she was involved in an effort to discredit a woman who had accused Gov. Andrew Cuomo of sexual harassment.
content: Roberta Kaplan resigned as chairwoman of Time’s Up after a report revealed she was involved in an effort to discredit a woman who had accused Gov. Andrew Cuomo of sexual harassment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Winona LaDuke Feels That President Biden Has Betrayed Native Americans

title: What You Get for $4.3 Million in California

author: By The New York Times
title: Fires in Evia, Greece, Force Thousands of Evacuations
description: The fires that have been raging in Greece for nearly a week show no signs of stopping. The biggest fire is in Evia, where thousands have already been evacuated. Many more are planning to evacuate by ferry in the coming days.
content: The fires that have been raging in Greece for nearly a week show no signs of stopping. The biggest fire is in Evia, where thousands have already been evacuated. Many more are planning to evacuate by ferry in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: U.S. Military Will Mandate Vaccinations for Troops
description: John Kirby, the Pentagon press secretary, said Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III will seek approval to make coronavirus vaccinations mandatory for U.S. active-duty troops by September.
content: John Kirby, the Pentagon press secretary, said Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III will seek approval to make coronavirus vaccinations mandatory for U.S. active-duty troops by September.

author: By The New York Times
title: A Race to Contain the Dixie Fire Amid Evacuation Orders
description: The Dixie Fire ravaging Northern California has become the state’s second-largest fire on record. Firefighters are working to save homes and towns being destroyed.
content: The Dixie Fire ravaging Northern California has become the state’s second-largest fire on record. Firefighters are working to save homes and towns being destroyed.

author: By Storyful
title: Flash Flooding Hits Omaha
description: A heavy downpour flooded buildings and roadways in eastern Nebraska over the weekend, and caused thousands of homes to lose power.

author: By Reuters
title: Canada Reopens Border to U.S. Travelers
description: Long lines formed at checkpoints after Canada reopened its southern border to fully vaccinated U.S. citizens and residents for non-essential travel. The border had been closed for over a year because of the coronavirus pandemic.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Joy of Plantains
description: The versatile fruit is as delicious in a skillet with tomatoes and eggs as it is alone, so why not make both?
content: Good morning. Yewande Komolafe is in The Times this week with a fantastically detailed and informative treatise on plantains that will, I hope, encourage you to cook with the fruit more than you already do — which may be often or may be not at all. Of course she has recipes to help you on your way: one for plantains with jammy tomatoes and eggs (above), which calls for firm yellow plantains; the other for the plantain fritters known as mosas, which calls for super-ripe, black-skinned plantains.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 9, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 9, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
